user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of mhd_tool_get_sys_cpu_count_special_api_:
```c
static int
mhd_tool_get_sys_cpu_count_special_api_ (void)
{
  int ret = -1;
#ifdef HAVE_PSTAT_GETDYNAMIC
  if (0 >= ret)
  {
    /* HP-UX things */
    struct pst_dynamic psd_data;
    memset ((void *) &psd_data, 0, sizeof (psd_data));
    if (1 == pstat_getdynamic (&psd_data, sizeof (psd_data), (size_t) 1, 0))
    {
      if (0 < psd_data.psd_proc_cnt)
        ret = (int) psd_data.psd_proc_cnt;
    }
  }
#endif /* HAVE_PSTAT_GETDYNAMIC */
#ifdef HAVE_VXCPUENABLEDGET
  if (0 >= ret)
  {
    /* VxWorks */
    cpuset_t enb_set;
    enb_set = vxCpuEnabledGet ();
    /* Count set bits */
    for (ret = 0; 0 != enb_set; enb_set &= enb_set - 1)
      ++ret;
  }
#endif /* HAVE_VXCPUENABLEDGET */
#if defined(_WIN32) && ! defined (__CYGWIN__)
  if (0 >= ret)
  {
    /* Native W32 */
    HMODULE k32hndl;
    k32hndl = LoadLibraryA ("kernel32.dll");
    if (NULL != k32hndl)
    {
      typedef DWORD (WINAPI *GAPC_PTR)(WORD GroupNumber);
      GAPC_PTR ptrGetActiveProcessorCount;
      /* Available on W7 or later */
      ptrGetActiveProcessorCount =
        (GAPC_PTR) (void *) GetProcAddress (k32hndl, "GetActiveProcessorCount");
      if (NULL != ptrGetActiveProcessorCount)
      {
        DWORD res;
        res = ptrGetActiveProcessorCount (ALL_PROCESSOR_GROUPS);
        ret = (int) res;
        if (res != (DWORD) ret)
          ret = -1; /* Overflow */
      }
    }
    if ((0 >= ret) && (NULL != k32hndl))
    {
      typedef void (WINAPI *GNSI_PTR)(SYSTEM_INFO *pSysInfo);
      GNSI_PTR ptrGetNativeSystemInfo;
      /* May give incorrect (low) result on versions from W7 to W11
         when more then 64 CPUs are available */
      ptrGetNativeSystemInfo =
        (GNSI_PTR) (void *) GetProcAddress (k32hndl, "GetNativeSystemInfo");
      if (NULL != ptrGetNativeSystemInfo)
      {
        SYSTEM_INFO sysInfo;

        memset ((void *) &sysInfo, 0, sizeof (sysInfo));
        ptrGetNativeSystemInfo (&sysInfo);
        ret = (int) sysInfo.dwNumberOfProcessors;
        if (sysInfo.dwNumberOfProcessors != (DWORD) ret)
          ret = -1; /* Overflow */
      }
    }
    if (NULL != k32hndl)
      FreeLibrary (k32hndl);
  }
  if (0 >= ret)
  {
    /* May give incorrect (low) result on versions from W7 to W11
       when more then 64 CPUs are available */
    SYSTEM_INFO sysInfo;
    memset ((void *) &sysInfo, 0, sizeof (sysInfo));
    GetSystemInfo (&sysInfo);
    ret = (int) sysInfo.dwNumberOfProcessors;
    if (sysInfo.dwNumberOfProcessors != (DWORD) ret)
      ret = -1; /* Overflow */
  }
#endif /* _WIN32 && ! __CYGWIN__ */
  if (0 >= ret)
    return -1;
  return ret;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I selected fragments that involve pointer use, pointer-to-function conversions, or void* casts where const-qualification of the pointed-to type might be relevant and therefore should be inspected for compliance with MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13. Other parts of the function do not require investigation for this rule because:

- Calls that pass addresses of objects intended to be modified (e.g., pstat_getdynamic(&psd_data, ...), ptrGetNativeSystemInfo(&sysInfo), GetSystemInfo(&sysInfo)) are output parameters and therefore should not be const-qualified.
- The cpuset_t enb_set variable and its bit-manipulation loop are not pointer uses and so are outside the scope of Rule 8.13.
- String literals (e.g., "kernel32.dll", "GetActiveProcessorCount", "GetNativeSystemInfo") are inherently immutable; the Windows APIs expect LPCSTR/LPCWSTR in their prototypes (const-qualified), so there is normally no additional const-qualification to enforce in this code beyond ensuring the API declarations are correct.
- Function pointer typedefs cannot sensibly apply a const qualifier to the function type itself in C (const on a function type is not meaningful), so typical function-pointer declarations are not flagged for this rule unless they involve pointers to data that could be const.

The listed fragments should be investigated to confirm whether any pointer types could or should be declared to point to const-qualified types, and to verify that the intermediate casts (especially via void*) do not inadvertently discard const qualifiers or violate the intent of Rule 8.13.
